claim: Vaccines do not permanently modify your DNA.

supporting.text: Vaccines work by stimulating the immune system to recognize pathogens, not by altering genetic material.

attacks.text: Vaccines work by stimulating the immune system to recognize pathogens, not by altering genetic material.
Some vaccines, like mRNA vaccines, introduce genetic material into cells, which could theoretically interact with DNA.
Studies show that mRNA from vaccines does not integrate into the genome and is degraded quickly by cellular processes.
Viral vector vaccines use modified viruses that can sometimes integrate into host DNA, though rarely.
Viral vectors used in vaccines are engineered to minimize integration risks and are rigorously tested for safety.

supporting.text: No approved vaccine uses a mechanism that integrates into or modifies the host's DNA.

attacks.text: No approved vaccine uses a mechanism that integrates into or modifies the host's DNA.
Some experimental gene therapies use viral vectors that could theoretically integrate into DNA, blurring the line between vaccines and genetic modification.
Approved vaccines strictly exclude such mechanisms, and regulatory agencies enforce clear distinctions between vaccines and gene therapies.
RNA vaccines introduce foreign nucleic acids, which could be reverse-transcribed into DNA under rare cellular conditions.
Studies show reverse transcription of vaccine RNA is biologically negligible, with no evidence of genomic integration in humans.

supporting.text: Scientific consensus confirms that vaccines interact with the immune system, not with cellular DNA.

attacks.text: Scientific consensus confirms that vaccines interact with the immune system, not with cellular DNA.
Some mRNA vaccines introduce genetic material into cells, which could theoretically interact with DNA under rare conditions.
Studies show that mRNA from vaccines degrades quickly and does not enter the cell nucleus where DNA is located.
Viral vector vaccines (e.g., adenovirus-based) can integrate into host DNA in extremely rare cases.
Regulatory agencies monitor viral vector vaccines for genomic integration, and no evidence of permanent modification exists.

supporting.text: DNA modification would require gene-editing technology, which is not used in any currently licensed vaccines.

attacks.text: DNA modification would require gene-editing technology, which is not used in any currently licensed vaccines.
Some mRNA vaccines introduce genetic material that could theoretically interact with cellular machinery, raising concerns about unintended DNA integration.
Studies have shown no evidence of mRNA vaccine genetic material integrating into human DNA under normal conditions.
Viral vector vaccines (e.g., adenovirus-based) deliver genetic material into cells, creating a theoretical pathway for DNA alteration.
Viral vector vaccines are designed to remain episomal and lack the mechanisms required for genomic integration.

supporting.text: Vaccine components such as mRNA or proteins are degraded by the body and do not persist in cells long-term.

attacks.text: Vaccine components such as mRNA or proteins are degraded by the body and do not persist in cells long-term.
Some studies suggest that under rare conditions, mRNA fragments could integrate into host DNA via reverse transcription mechanisms.
Reverse transcription of vaccine mRNA has never been observed in human clinical trials or real-world data, making this scenario highly speculative.
Certain viral vector vaccines (e.g., adenovirus-based) can enter the nucleus where DNA resides, raising theoretical concerns about integration.
Adenovirus vectors are engineered to lack integration machinery and have shown no evidence of genomic integration in decades of research.
